ygData.subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all, Our recent conversation in this Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results thread was started in part because a paper I am on was rejected from GECCO

Subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=nnra4VPafB7cojIyz8AN4Wk_TvtQVXm517tC94wtcaX_ZyuG9_yx
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello all,

Our recent conversation in this "Quantitative vs. Qualitative R=
esults" thread was started in part because a paper I am on was rejected fro=
m GECCO for not having any quantitative results. That paper was recently ac=
cepted at CEC. I'd be interested to hear your thoughts on this paper in lig=
ht of our conversation now that you can see the specific paper that was rej=
ected. 

I'd be especially interested to hear from those of you who argued =
that non-quantitative papers should be rejected (or, at least, should have =
a much higher threshold to gain acceptance). Obviously I think this paper i=
s interesting and will benefit the scientific community, partly because it =
suggests new ideas (though it can't quantify all of them yet). Do you think=
 our field is better off barring such papers because they can't quantitativ=
ely "prove" they are better than some alternate algorithm in some way? Of c=
ourse I'm not advocating that all papers should lack quantitative results; =
just that we should not rule out such papers if they don't have statistical=
 comparisons. I do want to stress that I always include--and as a reviewer,=
 insist upon--a statistical test with a p-value *if* a quantitative claim i=
s made, but that policy is not inconsistent with the view that many interes=
ting, subjective, qualitative observations are scientifically worthwhile to=
o. 

I won't take any criticism of our paper personally. I just think that =
sometimes arguments are more informative when there is a specific example t=
o be discussed, instead of remaining entirely abstract. I also think this p=
aper is a nice example of a technique that can't be quantified in an inform=
ative way, yet remains an interesting contribution. If you were our reviewe=
r, would you insist upon a quantitative comparison for this paper? How woul=
d you recommend such a test be made? Do you agree that we should encourage =
reviewers to reject such papers, or that we should work to encourage review=
ers to consider such papers?

Here is the cite and PDF: 

Clune J, Chen A, =
Lipson H (2013) Upload Any Object and Evolve it: Injecting Complex Geometri=
c Patterns into CPPNs for Further Evolution. Proceedings of the IEEE Congre=
ss on Evolutionary Computation.

http://jeffclune.com/publications/2013-Clu=
ne-SeededCPPN-CEC.pdf

I look forward to hearing your thoughts. 

Best rega=
rds,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming=

jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Nicolas Bre=
deche <nekonaute@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> It's really great we can have=
 this conversation here.
> 
> While I agree that papers with few results an=
d very good ideas should be
> published occasionally, I don't think things =
should be made easier. Indeed,
> Ken, you are the living proof that one can=
 publish novel ideas with
> qualitative results only(*) and, though getting=
 such papers accepted may be
> frustrating, it is the price to pay to avoid=
 getting *any* random ideas
> published. However, look at the benefit: once=
 accepted, how many works have
> been following the original idea of novelt=
y search or CPPN?
> 
> Moreover, let's keep in mind that for a conference/j=
ournal, there are
> several reviewers per paper, and then it is up to the e=
ditor or
> track/conference chair to check reviews for inconsistent or cont=
roversial
> papers, and ask for complementary reviews if needed -- As an ex=
ample with
> the GECCO 2013 ALIFE track, we provided at least 5 reviews per=
 paper, and
> up to 7 for controversial papers. ie. decisions end up as the=
 results from
> the combined work of individual reviewers and editors, rath=
er than being
> not just be numerical sum&averaging. In the end, a rejected=
 paper may be so
> because it has failed to convince the majority of review=
ers, would it be
> because it is too weak or out of topic wrt. the conferen=
ce/journal, but
> definitely not because a single reviewer killed the paper=
.
> 
> Of course, the fact that canonical, syntactically-correct, papers wi=
th
> quantitative results are more likely to get accepted is not a good thi=
ng
> either. If you look at the vast number of publications per year in our=

> field, there is already quite some noise (ie. papers that will be forgot=
ten
> for good or bad reasons), and few papers are actually used to inspire=
 new
> research in the years after - which can be seen more or less as an a=

> posteriori relevant evaluation of a paper's contribution.
> 
> It seems =
to me that the problem is not about accepting more or less papers
> with or=
 without qualitative results only, but about leaving more room/time
> to pr=
esentation and discussion around novel works, would they be with
> quantita=
tive or qualitative results -- On the one hand, the current oral
> presenta=
tion format in conferences, IMHO, partly fail to provide this
> space: leav=
ing 5 minutes for question is a bit ridiculous IMHO. On the
> other hand, t=
he poster sessions in most AI/EC conferences often leaves me
> very frustra=
ted (2 hours for more than one hundred posters, combined with a
> social ev=
ent), with the very notable exception of the PPSN conference
> (Parrallel P=
roblem Solving from Nature). At PPSN, there are only posters: a
> conferenc=
e chair (who read your paper) does approx. 3 minutes personal
> presentatio=
n/interpretation for a dozen of posters, and then you have ~2
> hours to wa=
nder around and visit posters, which often leads to you
> selecting 2-3 pos=
ters (There are several such sessions a day, in sequential
> order, without=
 any particular topic for a session). The time for discussion
> is therefor=
e significant enough to have a true scientific interaction.
> 
> A decent p=
oster session with a lower selection rate (~50%? unlike PPSN)
> would possi=
bly enable to take some risks with accepting contributions, and
> giving an=
yone the opportunity to present new ideas, without removing the
> fact that=
 if you want to get your work accepted for a conference talk or a
> journal=
 publication (with high selection rate), you have to work hard to
> convinc=
e reviewers and editors (as it is already the case for many
> journals). To=
 some extent, this is already done elsewhere, for example in
> the annual m=
eeting of the Society for Neuroscience (thousands of
> attendants, many man=
y posters, keynote talks).
> 
> Best,
> 
> Nicolas
> 
> 
> (*) don't get me=
 wrong, you also published many very good papers with
> quantitative result=
s ;-)
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 2013/4/22 Julian Togelius <julian@...>
